Generating Database Scripts Using SQL Server Management Studio

Posted by davidhayden on November 10, 2006

This should be filed under the category, "I am the only one who missed this!"

All this time I was questioning why SQL Server Management Studio wouldn't allow me to generate Database Scripts for all the objects in a database. This was extremely peculiar to me since SQL Server Management Studio uses SQL Server Management Objects, and it is extremely easy to use SMO to generate scripts, copy databases, etc:

  • Script SQL Server Database Using SQL Server Management Objects ( SMO ) and CaptureSql Mode – C# .NET 2.0
  • Copy Sql Server Database Schema and Data using SQL Server Management Objects and C# .NET 2.0

So as I am creating a database for integration testing and playing with SQL Refactor this week, I stumble upon the menu item Generate Scripts… shown below. Somehow I never noticed it in Tasks? I thought Script Database as (only for scripting the database object itself – not the contents ) and the scripting of individual objects were the only scripting options available. This week was the first I have seen of a wizard that lets you pick and choose multiple objects to script.

I now feel better about SQL Server Management Studio and its ability to script thanks to the fine wizard.  I take back all those unkind words I mumbled various evenings…

 

 

 

by David Hayden

  3. Stephen N says:
    November 11, 2006 at 4:00 am

    I wish I had seen this about three months ago because of the ANSI option towards the end of the wizard. I was using the “Script Database as”/”Script Table as” option which produces utf-16 text files. I tried to check these files into my subversion repo and had a fit trying to figure out why subversion thought the files were binary. The reason was that at the time subversion didn’t support utf-16. I don’t know if this is still the case but I am glad you did share because you just might save someone a day of banging their head against the wall.

  7. Damien Guard says:

    You might also want to check out Database projects from inside Visual Studio that give you various script options such as per-object and builds the .cmd file to run them all against a given server on the command line.

    It also lets you do ALTER scripts for db upgrades etc.
